A 'test tube', also known as a 'culture tube' or 'sample tube', is a common
piece of laboratory glassware consisting of a finger-like length of glass or
clear plastic tubing, open at the top, usually with a rounded U-shaped bottom.

A large test tube designed specifically for boiling liquids is called a
'[[boiling tube]]'.

Test tubes are available in a multitude of lengths and widths, typically from 10
to 20 mm wide and 50 to 200 mm
long. [http://catalog.miniscience.com/catalog/Glassware/Test_Tube.html
MiniScience.com catalog: Test Tube], accessed March 27, 2009 The top often
features a flared lip to aid pouring out the contents; some sources consider
that the presence of a lip is what distinguishes a test tube from a culture
tube. Thomas Scott (transl., 1996), Concise Encyclopedia: Biology. Walter de
Gruyter. ISBN 3-11-010661-2, ISBN 978-3-11-010661-9. 1287 pages. A test
tube has either a flat bottom, a round bottom, or a conical bottom. Some test
tubes are made to accept a ground glass stopper or a screw cap. They are often
provided with a small ground glass or white glaze area near the top for labeling
with a pencil.
